PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.   The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is necessary to (i) conduct 
thematic assessments; (ii) prepare medium-term roadmap and plans; (iii) carry out due 
diligence;  (iv)  prepare  report  and  recommendation  of  the  President  (RRP)  and  project 
administration manual (PAM); and (v) improve project readiness.   
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will have the following outputs produced through various assessments, 
consultations, and capacity building activities:  
(i)  Thematic  assessment  reports.  Through  desk  reviews,  surveys,  and 
stakeholder  consultations,  assessments  required  to  design  outputs  and 
activities related to pre-primary and inclusive education, kindergarten and 
school construction, expansion, and rehabilitation will be conducted.  
(ii)  Medium-term  roadmap  and  plans.  Medium-term  roadmap  and  plans  to 
achieve targets specified in the government’s plans and strategies will be 
prepared with inputs from the thematic assessments, institutional capacity 
assessment, and stakeholder consultations.  
(iii)  Economic, financial, governance, poverty, and social due diligence. The 
economic  and  financial  analyses  of  the  project  will  be  conducted  in 
accordance  with  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  guidelines.  Financial 
management and procurement capacity assessments will also be carried out 
and risks and mitigation measures will be identified. Based on poverty and 
social analysis, including gender analysis, gender and social action plans will 
be prepared. 
(iv)  Safeguards due diligence. The project is categorized B for environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. An initial environmental 
examination for the project will be conducted and a generic environment 
management plan (EMP) will be prepared. A social impact assessment will be 
carried out for resettlement, and where necessary, resettlement plans will be 
prepared. On ethnic minority issues, a detailed assessment will be performed 
and an ethnic minority development plan will be prepared.  
(v)  Report  and  recommendation  of  the  President,  and  project 
administration manual. Based on the above, the RRP and PAM will be 
drafted to ensure effective management and implementation of the project.  
(vi)  Training  and  preparation  of  procurement  and  consultant  recruitment 
packages. The project implementation unit will be established by the MECSS 
and provided with training on ADB’s policies and procedures. Engineering 
firm recruitment and some goods procurement packages will be prepared to 
be ready for advertisement.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The  PPTA  is  estimated  to  cost  $800,000  equivalent,  of  which  $800,000  will  be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, information, documents and 
data, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  A  total  of  20  person-months  of  international  and  44  person-months  of  national 
consulting services will be required. Individual consultants will be engaged (6.5 person-
months of international and 20 person-months of national consulting services) to conduct 
thematic assessments and related due diligence (environment and ethnic minorities), while 
13.5 person-months of international and 24 person-months of national consulting services 
will be engaged through a firm (quality- and cost-based selection [90:10]; simplified technical 
proposal) to develop the project design, conduct due diligence of the other aspects, and 
prepare the RRP and PAM. ADB will ensure coordination of the outputs developed by the 
individual consultants and the firm. All consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Output-based 
contracts and lump sum payments will be used under the TA.  
 
5.  Pre-primary  education  specialists  (international,  1.5  person-months;  national, 
4.0 person-months) and inclusive education specialists (international, 1.5 person-months; 
national, 4.0 person-months). Qualifications: a graduate degree in education; 10 years

(international), or 7 years (national) of experience in conducting policy-oriented research on 
pre-primary or inclusive education. Tasks: conduct thematic assessments on pre-primary 
and inclusive education to be used for the project design and medium-term roadmap and 
plans.  
 
6.  Ethnic  minority  education  specialist  (national,  3.0  person-months). 
Qualifications: a graduate degree in anthropology or sociology; 7 years of experience in 
researching  ethnic  minority  issues  in  the  education  sector.  Tasks:  conduct  a  detailed 
assessment of ethnic minority issues in the education sector in preparation of an ethnic 
minority development plan.  
 
7.  Physical  investment  planning  specialists  (international,  1.5  person-months; 
national, 4.0 person-months). Qualifications: a graduate degree in economics or education 
finance; 10 years of experience in conducting physical investment planning in the education 
sector (international), or 5 years of experience in working on physical investment plan and/or 
handling  education  statistics  (national).  Tasks:  (i)  prepare  a  thematic  assessment  on 
physical investment needs for kindergarten and school buildings and facilities; (ii) identify 
sites for kindergarten and school construction, expansion and rehabilitation; and (iii) conduct 
an analysis of the demand for energy efficient kindergartens and schools, and related costs 
(construction, operations and maintenance) and benefits.  
 
8.  Environment specialists (international, 2.0 person-months; national, 5.0 person-
months).  Qualifications:  a  graduate  degree  in  environment  sciences;  10  years 
(international), or 5 years (national) of experience in preparing environmental safeguards 
documentations.  Tasks:  (i)  review  potential  environmental  impacts  during  demolition  of 
school buildings for reconstruction, including handling and disposal of spoils, and possible 
new sites for kindergarten and schools to avoid areas with polluted soil; and (ii) conduct an 
initial environmental examination for the project, and prepare a generic EMP.   
 
9.  Education  specialist,  team  leader  (international,  5.0  person-months)  and 
education specialist, deputy team leader (national, 7.0 person-months). Qualifications: a 
graduate  degree  in  education;  10  years  of  experience  in  designing  education  projects 
(international),  or    7  years  of  experience  with  consultant  assignments  under  education 
projects (national). Tasks: (i) conduct an institutional capacity assessment, and identify 
measures to increase efficiency in public spending on education and strengthen institutional 
capacity in the education sector; (ii) review policies, statistics, and other materials related to 
pre-service and in-service teacher training; and (iii) design output 3 of the project.  
 
10.  Textbook and teaching-learning material specialists (international, 2.0 person-
months; national, 3.0 person-months). Qualifications: a graduate degree in education; 10 
years of experience in designing components related to textbooks and teaching-learning 
materials  (international),  or  7  years  of  experience  with  consultant  assignments  under 
education projects (national). Tasks: (i) conduct reviews of policies, statistics, and other 
materials; (ii) develop and carry out surveys; and (iii) design output 2 of the project.   
 
11.  Civil  engineers  and/or  architects  (international,  1.5  person-months;  national, 
3.0 person-months). Qualifications: a bachelor degree in civil engineering, or architecture; 
10 years (international), or 7 years (national) of experience in designing education facilities. 
Tasks: (i) prepare preliminary designs and specifications, and cost estimates of kindergarten 
and school construction, expansion, and rehabilitation; and (ii) ensure that kindergartens and 
schools supported by the project will be connected to municipal services and/or others for 
water supply, waste, and wastewater collection and/or treatment, and heating. 
 
12.  Resettlement  specialists  (international,  1.0  person-month;  national,  3.0  person-
months). Qualifications: a graduate degree in sociology; 10 years (international), or 5 years 
(national) of experience in conducting socioeconomic surveys, and preparing involuntary

4 
 
resettlement safeguards documentations. Tasks: (i) conduct a social impact assessment for 
resettlement; and (ii) prepare resettlement plans, where necessary.  
 
13.  Poverty, gender, and social specialists (international, 1.5 person-months; national, 
3.0  person-months).  Qualifications:  a  graduate  degree  in  sociology;  10  years 
(international), or 7 years (national) of experience in conducting socioeconomic surveys, 
gender analysis, poverty and social analysis, and preparing social and gender action plans 
and ethnic minority development plans. Tasks: (i) conduct poverty and social analysis, 
including gender analysis; and (ii) prepare a gender and social action plan, and an ethnic 
minority development plan.  
 
14.  Economists  (international,  1.0  person-month;  national,  2.0 person-months). 
Qualifications. a graduate degree in economics or finance; 10 years (international), or 5 
years  (national)  of  experience  in  preparing  cost  estimates,  conducting  economic  and 
financial analyses of projects. Tasks: (i) prepare costs estimates and financial projections; 
and (ii) conduct economic and financial analyses of the project in accordance with ADB’s 
guidelines.  
 
15.  Financial  management  specialists  (international,  1.5  person-months;  national, 
3.0 person-months). Qualifications: a graduate degree in public financial management, 
accounting,  or  law  with  a  recognized  professional  accountancy  qualification;  10  years 
(international), or 5 years (national) of experience in conducting financial management and 
procurement  capacity  assessments.  Tasks:  (i)  conduct  financial  management  and 
procurement capacity assessments; and (ii) prepare a risk assessment and management 
plan.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The  MECSS  will  be  the  executing  and  implementing  agency  of  the  PPTA. The 
MECSS will establish a steering committee to review and comment on the project design, 
medium-term  roadmap  and  plans,  and  other  project  documents.  The  PPTA  will  be 
implemented from November 2016 to September 2018. The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed in line with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time).
